column3:
Instructions for the Bamboo charts gadget

Steps:
1. Login to QA-JAC and add bamboo chart gadget hosted on JBAC.
2. In the preferences window, select the builds,select "Group By" as weekly,show builds from as "last 30 days" and refresh interval as "Every 30 mins". Save it.
3. It display the chart with desired build and group by weekly info.
4. Click to any other dashboard or any other menu of JIRA and back to the dashboard having bamboo gadget.

Result:
1. The chart is different, opening the preferences dialog show "Group By" and "Refresh Interval" is reset to default and not getting saved.

Expected:
1. The preferences for gadget should be saved.

column3:
A deciding factor between CI tools for us was the ability for developers to be able to trigger builds at-will over XMPP in addition to scheduled builds. 

Unfortunately, Atlassian has lost $8k from us, as we have decided to go with Hudson, since their ability to trigger builds via XMPP has proven more valuable than Bamboo's outstanding integration with Jira.

However, if this feature is developed in the near-term, we may reconsider purchasing Bamboo.
column4: XMPP-based Build Triggering

column3:
In case a (scheduled) build fails to checkout/update the build fails.
Bamboo should retry the repository operations a few times before giving up and failing the build.
Scheduled builds are not at risk of repository failures and will not run until next scheduled.


Edit: This is actually more of an headache on Windows, where customers often have anti-virus or windows defender running. And sometimes a force clean build will fail, due to anti-virus locking the file.
column4: Bamboo should retry Repository related operation before failing a build

column3:
Our project currently uses Maven, Bamboo and Sonar.
We noticed a difference between the test counts reported by Bamboo and Sonar.

Bamboo seems to count ignored tests (@Ignore annotation) while Sonar excludes ignore tests. For example we have a build plan that shows 109 tests executed in Bamboo while Sonar show 106 tests executed and 3 ignored.

This is very confusing to our development community. It would be better if Bamboo showed total tests, executed tests and ignored tests.
column4: Bamboo is counting ignored JUnit tests.

column3:
We apparently need to repackage the plugin.  Don't entirely understand why...




From Justus:

The short version:

I just checked in a change to JIRA that will require plugins to be recompiled and redeployed as a new version but shouldn't require any source changes in order to work with our next release of JIRA 4.0. If you have questions, problems, or my claims about it just being a simple recompile turn out to be a dirty lie, let me know ASAP and we can work through the issues.


The longer version:

The FieldVisibilityBean is a concrete class. This causes problems in OSGi/plugins2 because it doesn't implement an interface that we can proxy to Spring. This means that it can't be constructor injected and people who need a FieldVisiblityBean have to come up with hacks and workarounds.

I just checked in a fix for JRA-18431 (which comes from AGS-1394) in svn revision 97568 which introduces a FieldVisibilityManager interface and FieldVisibilityManagerImpl implementation.

The FieldVisibilityBean is still in place but is deprecated.

The biggest visible change is that certain constructors (in Indexers, Renderers, and Searchers) now take a FieldVisibilityManager instead of a FieldVisibilityBean. Since you were passing in a FieldVisibilityBean before, and FieldVisibilityBean implements FieldVisibilityManager, there should be no source code changes required.
column4: Update JIRA plugin to use FieldVisibilityManager rather than FieldVisibilityBean

column3:
* on the build config screen if a "global" license exists then we display a message indicating that a license is already configured.
* on the build config screen if a "global" license exists AND the license is valid then we display a message indicating that a license is valid.
* on the build config screen if a "global" license exists AND the license is invalid then we display a message indicating that a license is NOT valid
* on the build config screen if NO "global" license exists then a text entry field should be available and a message indicating that a license is required should be displayed.
* a text entry field should be available on the build config screen to allow the license to be overridden at the plan level.
* If _any_ license is defined at a plan level, it takes precedence

* Check interaction with clover.license in the settings.xml*
Validation of lic. is optional nice to have iff extras supports decoding.
column4: Allow a clover license to be entered via the Bamboo admin (ie a global license).  License can be overridden at the plan config level

Since most (all?) build artifacts are static, and probably never change once they are created, Bamboo should set the "Last Modified" header when serving any artifact.
The timestamp from the file stored on disk could be used, or if that is unavailable - the time stamp of when the build finished?

!http://img.skitch.com/20090819-me3phuunma1um3acd6jpdddkxt.jpg!

Large artifacts such as the JSON needed for Clover's new Tree Map could greatly benefit from browsers doing the needful caching.

column3:
My use case is starting my elastic instances in the morning and shutting down in the evening because my load requirements follow that pattern. Theoretically BAM-3078 and BAM-3077 will achieve this.

I can script the starting up and shutting down of my instances today, but experimentation has shown that the EBS volume creation and mounting is not reliable, especially when multiple instances are started at once. I can ssh into the instances and see if the ebs volume was mounted, but I need the IP address of the machine first.

Currently the REST API can't help me since it returns only this sort of thing:

{code}
<response>
−
<instance>
<id>i-97a481fe</id>
<state>RUNNING</state>
<uptime>3023836</uptime>
</instance>
−
<instance>
<id>i-47d1f42e</id>
<state>RUNNING</state>
<uptime>8406836</uptime>
</instance>
−
<instance>
<id>i-d1d5f0b8</id>
<state>RUNNING</state>
<uptime>9329837</uptime>
</instance>
−
<instance>
<id>i-3dd5f054</id>
<state>RUNNING</state>
<uptime>9586837</uptime>
</instance>
−
<instance>
<id>i-0bd4f162</id>
<state>RUNNING</state>
<uptime>9133837</uptime>
</instance>
</response>
{code}

To get what I want I have to either scrape the screen, hack bamboo or use the AWS API to determine the hostname in a separate remote call.
column4: Add Elastic Instance hostname/IP address to REST API for listRunningInstances.action

column3:
To allow Clover 'one-click' integration of bamboo builds, the bamboo-clover plugin needs to do the following:

h3. Ant
Append configuration of the form {{-lib clover.jar -Dclover.option=option ...}} to the Ant Builder command line.
See also: http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CLOV-431

h3. Maven
Append:
{{clover2:instrument clover2:aggregate clover2:clover}}
to the command line.

h3. Set and Collect Clover build artifacts.
The following system artifacts need to then be configured by the plugin:
* clover.xml
* clover/html
* clover.snapshot (plan level)
* clover-history.tar.gz (plan level)
column4: Provide a plugin point to decorate the builder command line

This causes intermittent problems with the Freemarker & webwork. If we rename the methods on the top level interfaces (suffix with V2) that should be fine

column3:
There are a few inefficiencies in the way we are currently using the EC2 web services:

- When we start multiple instances simultaneously, we are making a separate request for each, rather than a single request for multiple instances.
- We are polling for the status of each instance separately, rather than using a single call.
- We are polling for the status of volumes attached to each instance separately, rather than using a single call.

We can increase the scalability of Elastic Bamboo by replacing these multiple per-instance calls with more efficient multiple-instance calls.
column4: Improve scalability of EC2 web service calls

column3:
Screen Requirements:
*  AWS Access Key ID
* AWS Secret Access Key (protected by a password-type text field)
* Maximum number of Elastic Instances (must be specified, no default, allowable range: 0 - number of remote agents allowed by license)
* Disclaimer stating they have accepted the terms and conditions
* Link to terms and conditions.
* Link to help information - where can they find the access key and secret access hey

Screen Functionality
* Add - validation that the details are correct (security group check stuff will be handled per agent creation).
* Edit 
** Access Key ID - validation that the details are correct, any running agents destroyed, recreate new elastic agents as necessary for the queue (there may be timing issues here)
** Secret Key - validation that details are correct
** Max Agents  - if reduced existing instances are terminated to enforce the limit. Preference is given to terminating idle instances, if increased new Elastic Instances are created in response to the current contents of the queue.  
* Disable - any running elastic agents destroyed

column3:
Currently, the same broker URI must be used to bind the broker transport, and to connect to it from agents.

This prevents the failover transport from being used on the agents, as a failover scheme URI cannot be used to bind the Broker transport.

Bamboo should provide the ability to configure distinct broker URIs for binding the broker transport, and for connecting to the Broker from agents.
column4: Support for distinct client and server broker URIs

column3:
Bamboo currently automatically adds "wireFormat.maxInactivityDuration=0" to any Broker URL.  However, there are a few problems with its implementation:

# It ignores the transport being used, adding it even to transports that don't accept such a parameter.
# It discards some components of valid Broker URLs (e.g. using the failover scheme).
# It doesn't apply the parameter to nested URLs (e.g. tcp scheme URLs nested within a failover scheme URL.

This is preventing the use of the failover transport to solve BAM-2999.
column4: Valid Broker URLs are ruined by attempt to add "maxInactivityDuration"

column3: It appears from looking at log files that each individual file in an artifact collection is transmitted as a single JMS message. This isn't particularly great for a lot of our plans, where we copy over a hierarchy of JUnit HTML and Clover HTML reports. They can take many minutes to copy the artifacts (where artifact copying takes far longer than the actual build itself).\r\n\r\nWould it be possible to batch up artifact copying in some way to reduce the length of time it takes to copy large numbers of small files?

column3:
Chat transcript:

6:26:23 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: we need a modification to the bamboo API
6:27:37 PM Edwin: ok.
6:27:57 PM Edwin: which one? when?
6:28:03 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: in the build info
6:28:04 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: the commit files
6:28:06 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: that come back
6:28:08 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: have no full path
6:28:14 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: and you can't get (remotely) the SCM details
6:28:18 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: so you get /PL/foo/pom.xml
6:28:22 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: but you don't know which repo!
6:30:17 PM Edwin: but each plan is always tied to one repo?
6:30:29 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: right - but how can I know that remotely?
6:31:19 PM Edwin: buildPlanDefinition.getRepository?
6:32:53 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: hrm - let me look
6:33:08 PM Edwin: hm. which remote API are you calling?
6:33:19 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: getBuildInfo
6:34:25 PM Edwin: build info?
6:34:30 PM Edwin: this is against trunk?
6:36:08 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: let me check the exact method we're calling
6:36:18 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: you get back like <commitfile>/PL/pom.xml</commitfile>
6:39:50 PM Edwin: right.
6:40:02 PM Edwin: think you're calling getBuildResultsDetails
7:49:59 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: uhm, yup - that's the one
7:50:20 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: really I think we should return something like <commitfile>/PL... </commitfile><repository>http://svn.atlassian.com... </repository> ?
7:50:35 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: or even <commitfile repository="">/PL... </commitfile>
7:50:42 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: makes it easier to get hte info you need in one call
7:50:48 PM Mike Cannon-Brookes: and if we do the second we don't markedly change the API
column4: Include identity of repository in response to getBuildResultsDetails Remote API method

column3:
New Perforce Library Does not support perforce versions BEFORE 2005.1

In 2005.1 the following synonyms were created to run on the command line

synonymn           command
--------                    -------
changelist           change
changelists         changes
workspace          client
workspaces        clients

In 2001.1
	    #0 is now a synonym for #none when specifying (no) revisions.

We need to check where they get used, remove them, and retest.
column4: Bamboo 2.0 does not support perforce versions BEFORE 2005.1

column3: "There are currently 1 remote agent online. 1 agentare supported by your license."\r\n\r\nIt's missing a space, and should read "is", rather than "are" when only 1 agent is supported.
column4: Typo on agents admin page

column3:
If a Perforce command does not execute due to: 

Request too large (over 500000); see 'p4 help maxresults'.

This response is not caught as an error and is therefore parsed for the expected response, which can cause some unpredictable behaviour especially for the 'changes' command.  The perforce library should have this as one of the error messages it  'looks out for' and errors out appropriately.
column4: Perforce library does not handle the error message "Request too large"

column3: It is often the case that there are multiple build plans that make use of a shared resource in the testing environment, and that running these concurrently causes problems.\r\n\r\nBamboo needs a mechanism, such as a special kind of build requirement, that prevents such build plans from being run concurrently.
column4: Mechanism to prevent builds that use a shared resource from running concurrently
Setup JDK 1.6 functional tests on Panda

column3:
It is possible to navigate to an artifact from the latest build using a URL of the form:

[base URL]/download/[project key]-[plan key]/artifacts/latest/[artifact name]

At present, this is implemented by generating a static HTML file containing a client-side refresh.

This has at least a couple of disadvantages:
# It does not work well with tools such as wget and curl, that do not make use of the client-side refresh; and
# [It breaks if an artifact is subsequently deleted|BAM-1743].

We should instead dynamically generate a [302 Found|http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2616#section-10.3.3] response.
column4: Reimplement "latest" artifact URLs as 302 redirects, rather than client-side refreshes

column3:
Steps to reproduce:

1- Run build on remote agent
2- restart remote agent within 2min while building
3- look at current activity screen of plan v dashboard (for agent)..

Fix:

We should track a start up time for every time an agent reports a heartbeat. If the start up time has changed - the agent has restarted and we should publish an agent restarted event to handle the scenario (similar to what happens when the heartbeatcheckerjob detects an agent has fully gone offline).
column4: Remote agent restart can leave builds in a building state while the agent reports it is idle
Document advice on overcoming import/export problems due to the use of the coverage plug-in(s)

column3:
I would like an authentication mode where the appearance of the basic authentication username indicates that user is properly authenticated into this service.  We're using Apache + SSL + Tomcat + mod_jk + mod_auth_kerb to authenticate against an AD-based  Kerberos Domain Controller for other services, and we would like to delegate authentication for Bamboo to our current distributed authentication configuration as well.

os_authType=basic gets us most of the way there, but bamboo wants to test the Basic Authentication passcode against its own stored copy.  What we want is for the passcode to live in Active Directory, without requiring Bamboo to have login credentials to access Active Directory directly.

BTW, aside from the use of Kerberos, this feature would also be useful to organizations which are already using some kind of Basic Authentication within their web server to protect other assets, and who don't need Bamboo to maintain extra copies of the passcode.

Maybe said feature might be triggered by os_authType=basic_deferred ?
column4: Basic Authentication

column3: People occasionally need agent specific variables to be passed to a build. It'd be very handy to be able to allow capability values to be passed down to the agents, maybe in the format {{capability.<key>}} or something.

column3: Right now, the requirements can show each requirement being met by at least one agent, but you still have no agents matching ALL the requirements. It's quite a challenge to work out what is needed to be done to get this build to run on any agent. Related to this, we also don't really  know which requirements is causing an agent not to be executable against a plan.\r\n\r\nThe suggestion is to add a list/matrix down the bottom showing up to 3 agents which are closest to matching the requirements (most matched requirements), and display the requirements which these agents fail on. That way, it's much clearer to the user how to fix the plan/agent so that it can run.
column4: Build Requirement Configuration page should indicate which how agents are not meeting requirements

column3:
There seems to be some authentication issues with Perforce repositories.

If I put in a user that does not exist, it correctly returns: "This user is not available on this port (Perforce server)"

If I put in no username, though my current system username exists, it returns: "The perforce user has not been defined"

If I type in a valied perforce username and password, it returns: "Unable to connect to the perforce server, please ensure that your login details are correct"

It appears that it is able to see the server and validate a username, but it won't accept any password whatsoever.

The logfile does not seem to log the command that it is trying to run, either, like Bamboo 1.2.4 so it's difficult to see where the failure happens and what exactly it's trying to do.

Note that we are using an authentication trigger that authenticates against an Active Directory domain. This process works fine in 1.2.4. Extremely verbose log file attached.
column4: Perforce repo still not working on Windows machine

column3: When viewing the requirements for a plan, it's pretty hard to find the dropdown which displays the agents that can run the build.  Perhaps the text "This plan can only be built by agents whose capabilities meet the 3 requirements below. 4 agents are capable of building the plan." should have some highlighting (or a little info icon maybe) to let the user know that there's more info there when you hover the mouse over it.  I would also find it useful to find out which agents *can't* build this current plan.\r\n\r\nThe same applies for the admin section where you can configure the agent.  It would be good to be able to see the builds an agent *can't* build, so that I can click through to those builds requirements and figure out why they're not being built.  Maybe add a little toggle "Show builds agent can't build", which is hidden by default and if clicked pops up the list of builds an agent can't build.
column4: Improve the feedback about which agents can build a plan, and what builds an agent can build

column3:
Variable substitution doesn't seem to work in Bamboo 2.0 beta.

For e.g, passing down svn=${bamboo.custom.svn.revision.number} to a bash script in Bamboo 2.0 beta, doesn't pass down the SVN revision number.

Reported in https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-578

column3:
It'd handy to be able to pass down metadata about the parent build that triggerred off the current build. This will allow the information to be passed into the build process (e.g. Maven) to use this information to chain their builds. 

So you might have:

{noformat}
dependency.parent.0 = JRA-MAIN-102
dependency.parent.1 = JRA-UNIT14-56
dependency.parent.2 = JRA-FUNC14-12
{noformat}

where JRA-MAIN-102 is the originating build that kicked off this entire tree. We could even add some extra tool to show this graphically

{{bamboo.dependency.parent.0}} would be available to the underlying build process where it could be used to retrieve artifacts or extra information about the originating build.
column4: Dependencies should pass down meta data about the dependency chain

column3:
The automatic installer on Mac finishes with the message "The application may be launched by double-clicking the installed icons".

This isn't true for Bamboo.  Bamboo must be started by executing a script from the command line.

We should fix this.  It could lead to confusing and disappointing first impressions.
column4: Misleading message in final step of Mac installer

At the same time call form Firefox returns valid data.
column4: User context in remote API is not tied to authentication token

column3:
TestNG (a successor to JUnit) provides a mechanism that lets you skip execution of tests whenever prior tests upon which they depend fail. Such tests are reported as being "skipped", as opposed to either "passed" or "failed".

We need to implement support for this third category of test results.

Surefire 2.4 provides support for reporting "skipped" tests.
column4: Implement support for TestNG's ability to skip tests

column3: This is due to autodetected JDKs on 1.2.4 having labels of the form "X.X.X_XX", whereas autodetected JDKs on 2.0 have labels of the form "JDK X.X.X_XX".\r\n\r\nWe should modify the importer and upgrader to add the "JDK " prefix when labels match the autodetected form.

column3:
If there are no plans defined, every agent admin page states "This agent cannot execute any plans due to missing requirements".

This is misleading.  It should instead state, "This agent cannot execute any plans, as no plans are defined".

(While we're at it, I don't think the wording of "This agent cannot execute any plans due to missing requirements" is quite right.  How about, "This agent cannot execute any plans, as its capabilities don't match the requirements of any plan."?)
column4: "This agent cannot execute any plans due to missing requirements" misleading when no plans defined

column3: Surefire 2.4 has changed the JUnit report format which breaks test telemetry \r\n\r\nUse the Surefire 2.4 repository at http://people.apache.org/~dfabulich/staging-repo/ to test the scope of the problem
column4: Test metrics broken when using Surefire 2.4

column3: In some environments, an unknown third-party application is adding the line "-e" to the beginning of mailcap files.  JavaMail fails to parse these files and throws an NullPointerException.  See [BSP-442|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-442] for an example.\r\n\r\nBamboo should detect this problem, and make allowance for it.
column4: Detection and handling of invalid mailcap file

column3: This often results in Bamboo being started with an incompatible JRE (e.g. libgcj - see [BSP-447|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-447]).\r\n\r\nTo fix this, $JAVA_HOME/bin/ needs to be added to the beginning of RUN_CMD.
column4: bamboo.sh assumes that the correct "java" executable is on the path

column3:
As seen in [BSP-439|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-439], if the text "BUILD SUCCESSFUL" appears in the last 100 lines of a build that ultimately fails and produces a "BUILD FAILED" message, Bamboo's Ant and Maven builder misinterpret this as a successful build.

To address this issue, these builders should also search for "BUILD FAILED" messages as well, and act on the last message found in the build log.

As a workaround, you can control the number of lines that Bamboo searches for a "BUILD SUCCESSFUL" message, by setting an environment variable named "SUCCESS_MESSAGE_LINES" before starting Bamboo.  You can disable this search completely, relying solely on the return code of your build, by setting this environment variable to 0.
column4: "BUILD SUCCESSFUL" appearing shortly before a final "BUILD FAILED" message is misinterpreted as a successful build

column3: Problems can occur when a Bamboo instance is run on an unsupported JRE (e.g [BSP-437|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-437]).\r\n\r\nTo ease diagnosis of this situation, Bamboo should, as part of its bootstrapping, check the JRE, and produce a prominent warning in the logs if it is not one of the JREs explicitly supported by Bamboo.
column4: Include a prominent warning in the Bamboo log when running on an unsupported JRE

column3: The Maven2 builder in Bamboo should use the --batch-mode option on Maven's command line to instruct Maven that it is a non-interactive build.
column4: Maven2 builder should add --batch-mode to command line

column3: Although Throwable implements Serializable, in practice there are Throwables that are not serialisable.  For this reason, we shouldn't attempt to serialise Throwables to send them over JMS.
column4: Rework ErrorUpdateHandler interface to accommodate non-serialisable Throwables.

column3: We are encountering regular problems caused by serialisation of unnecessary objects.  We need visibility of what is actually being included in the serialised object graph being passed in ObjectMessages.
column4: Logging of serialized object graph

column3: To avoid the possibility of data corruption, we should detect when Bamboo has been started with a database that has already been upgraded by a later version of Bamboo.\r\n
column4: Prevent Bamboo from being run with a database that has been upgraded by a later version

column3: It is possible to start multiple Bamboo processes running against the same Bamboo home.  This has been the underlying cause of a number of support issues.\r\n\r\nWe should prevent this by implementing a mechanism that prevents multiple instances of Bamboo being started against a single Bamboo home.  This mechanism would probably make use of some kind of lock file.
column4: Prevent multiple instances of Bamboo from using the same database

column3: This, amongst other things, enables the Plugin Repository to be used.
column4: Servlet plugin point

column3: We should allow labelling and commenting of test cases, at both a per-build and per-plan level.\r\n\r\nThis would be particularly useful for making and sharing notes on test cases that are failing intermittently (at a per-plan level), or sharing notes on who is investigating a particular failure (at a per-build level).
column4: Extend label and comment features to test cases

column3:
Due to limitations of the original ZIP file format, and the TrueZIP library used to generate ZIP files, it is not possible to export a Bamboo instance when the resulting ZIP file, or the original size of any of its components, are larger than 4G.

We should adopt an export file format and that does not have this constraint.  ZIP64? .tar.gz? .tar.bz?

We will need to maintain support for importing ZIP exports produced by older versions of Bamboo.
column4: Cannot create export files larger than 4G

column3:
As a consequence of BAM-402, when a user clicks on a build artifact, it will always be downloaded, rather than displayed in the browser.

This is not appropriate for all artifact types.

We should set the Content-Disposition header to "inline" for text, image, audio & video Content-Types, so that they are displayed in the browser, when possible.
column4: Implement rules to determine whether an artifact is to be downloaded or viewed in the browser

column3:
There are some kinds of artifacts that users would like to open immediately (e.g. log files) and others that they would like to download (e.g. jar files).

Bamboo 1.2.2 lets the browser decide on the appropriate action based on the Content-Type.  Bamboo determines the Content-Type based on the file extension, and defaults to text/html if the file extension is unrecognised.

As a consequence of BAM-402, Bamboo 1.2.3 will force the browser to download the file.  This is a change in behaviour, and may not be what the user requires.

We should let the user decide by removing the hyperlink from artifact names, and instead offering "view" and "download" links next to each artifact name.  We should use the [Content-Disposition header|http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2183] to control this.
column4: Let the user decide whether they want to view or download an artifact

column3:
We currently use atlassian-base 1.5 as the parent of atlassian-bamboo.

It includes some unnecessary dependencies, including junit and jmock in the default scope, rather than the "test" scope.

This is causing these JARs to be packaged in the Agent Bootstrap.

I don't believe that Maven 2 currently provides a way to exclude dependencies specified by a parent POM.

We should upgrade to a newer version.
column4: Move to a newer version of atlassian-base

column3:
I think a really useful feature would be to have markers in the " Build Duration & Number of Failures per Build" diagram, that mark at which time 25% of the successfull builds were reached, at which time 50% were reached, etc.

This would give some Information about whether success was primarily in the distant past or near the present.

Otherwise I have to count the total number of successfull builds, calculate the percentages and habe to count from the beginning to find out something about the temporal distribution of failed builds.

I would do it myself if I had access to the source.
column4: DIagram: Distribution of the "Mass" of successfull builds over time.

column3:
The expected element type of the List returned by implementations of BuildResult.getBuildLog() and accepted by BuildResult.setBuildLog(List) is undocumented.

At least one plugin assumes that the element type is the SimpleLogEntry class (see BAM-1375), when I believe the intention is that be the LogEntry interface.

We should document this before too many third party plugins make the same mistake.

Also, we should check our own implementations of this interface.
column4: Type of build log entries is undocumented in Javadoc

column4: Deadlock issue while view currently running build

column3: This means if you are building something which has a dependency on the path, it probably won't work
column4: PATH variable gets clobbered in JDK 1.4

column3: Selecting users under administration is extremely slow with LDAP. Taking as long as 33 minutes for the list of users to appear. \r\n\r\nSee Support issue (https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-92)
column4: User and group browser very slow in LDAP environment

column3:
Selecting users under administration is extremely slow with LDAP. Taking as long as 33 minutes for the list of users to appear. 

Sometimes the complete list of users is returned and sometimes the following exception is generated after approximately 30 minutes of waiting for the list of users:

FreeMarker template error!

column3: Ability to pick in the repository whether to set the force synch flag on or off in Perforce.\r\n\r\nA work around to this is to go to "Fies -> Delete all files", which will cause Bamboo to re-checkout from Perforce.
column4: Ability to pick force synch flag in Perforce

column3:
It would be nice to be able to turn on and off various logging like Jira does

Especially so we can turn the access logging on and off.
column4: Logging Configuration Screen

column3: The remove plans screen have the plans in randometical order
column4: Ordering of the remove plans screen

column3: In the tooltip that appears when you hover over a user in the dashboard does not deal with backslashes (\) properly.  It seems to be trying to interpret them as escape sequences.\r\n\r\nSee the attached screenshot.  In this case, the username in subversion is 5D\tchu but when bamboo tries to display it in the tooltip, it looks like it interpreted the \t to mean a tab.
column4: Backslashes in usernames not displayed correctly on tooltip

column3:
Builds triggered by dependencies are not reported correctly in email notifications. Instead they are reported as initial or manual builds.

It would be even better if dependency builds indicated which dependency triggered the build.

Originally a Support request - https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-85
column4: Dependency builds incorrectly reported as initial or manual build in email notifications

column3:
Running the "Confluence - Unit test" on JDK 1.4 fails on the Bamboo instance running on Keg. 
It succeeds running it against JDK 1.5.

Running the same tests on the same server, same JDK, same Maven is fine outside of Bamboo...

I ran then using maven debug mode and it seems that with JDK 1.4 configured there are some JDK 1.5 libraries on the classpath which could be the cause of the problem.
http://keg.sydney.atlassian.com:8080/bamboo/build/viewBuildLog.action?buildKey=CONF-MAIN&buildNumber=1717

Here is an extract of the debug trace:

column3:
I've created a plan that hasn't yet been built, and was browsing the tabs to see what information was available.  The 'Completed Builds' tab has the following text on it:
    "Bamboo builds everything whenever the Subversion source code repository changes."

...but the build strategy for plan for my project is "Manual builds only".
column4: Text on 'Completed Builds' page doesn't match plan build strategy.

column3: This may not necessarily be correct as the script (especially self defined builders) may not need an argument.
column4: Arguments field in bash script/script builders are mandatory

column3: The Ant builder looks for the text "BUILD SUCCESSFUL" in the last 5 lines of the build logs. However, that may not always be correct as some logging (e.g. shutdown code) may push the ant "BUILD SUCCESSFUL" message beyond the designated 5 lines.\r\n\r\nThis requirement should be relaxed.
column4: Ant builder checks last 5 lines for BUILD SUCCESSFUL

column3: When having a single build queue and you remove that queue, you get a warning message stating you should always have a build queue in order to perform builds, but the queue is removed anyway.\r\n\r\nProblem is, you can't add any new queues when the last one is gone. I had to alter the configurePipeline.ftl in the webapp/admin folder to always display the "new" queue fields in order to add a new queue.
column4: Removing last build queue blocks use

column3:
The start_bamboo wrapper script uses "uname" in a way Debian does not recognize:

cruise@bamboo:~/bamboo$ ./wrapper/start-bamboo status
Try `uname --help' for more information.

The problem is "uname -p"
column4: start-bamboo wrapper uses false uname syntax

column3:
The user profile for any given user is visible even when not logged in.  The profile page lists: username, Full Name, email, Jabber Address, Groups, and Source Repository Alias.  Much of this information is semi-private and shouldn't be publically displayed.  Especially email addresses, as that opens up massive spam.  Please consider hiding email, Jabber Address & groups.

An example user profile page is at: https://www.limewire.org/bamboo/browse/user/sam
column4: Hide User Info From Non-Admins

column3:
Minor issue, attached screenshot says it all.

Expected behavior: comment hover text should be above all other page elements
Actual behavior: comment hover text is obscured by page footer
column4: z-index of comment hover text is lower than other page elements

column3:
Bamboo frequently reports the error "Failed to get the build source code" after being triggered by a SVN  commit. The apparent cause from the stack trace is that the connection to Subversion has been reset. This causes Bamboo to execute a clean operation followed by an update which then succeeds. Several other build systems tested in this same environment against the same repository do not exhibit similar issues.


com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: Meritas Continuous - SERVER
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.svn.SvnRepository.getChangesSinceLastBuild(SvnRepository.java:376)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.strategy.PollingBuildStrategy.requiresBuild(PollingBuildStrategy.java:126)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.DefaultBuildChangeDetector.checkIfBuildNeedsBuilding(DefaultBuildChangeDetector.java:166)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.DefaultBuildChangeDetector.doTask(DefaultBuildChangeDetector.java:114)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.DefaultBuildChangeDetector.run(DefaultBuildChangeDetector.java:77)
	at edu.emory.mathcs.backport.java.util.concurrent.helpers.ThreadHelpers$1.run(ThreadHelpers.java:34)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:595)
Caused by: org.tmatesoft.svn.core.SVNException: svn: Connection reset
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.wc.SVNErrorManager.error(SVNErrorManager.java:48)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.svn.SVNReader.parse(SVNReader.java:360)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.svn.SVNConnection.read(SVNConnection.java:206)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.svn.SVNConnection.authenticate(SVNConnection.java:92)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.svn.SVNRepositoryImpl.authenticate(SVNRepositoryImpl.java:983)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.internal.io.svn.SVNRepositoryImpl.update(SVNRepositoryImpl.java:565)
	at org.tmatesoft.svn.core.wc.SVNUpdateClient.doUpdate(SVNUpdateClient.java:162)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.svn.SvnRepository.update(SvnRepository.java:713)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.svn.SvnRepository.getChangesSinceLastBuild(SvnRepository.java:353)
column4: Bamboo source update problem: "Failed to get the build source code"

column3: While externals' changes are being picked up, the fisheye link for the changed files are not correct (it assumes the files are under the root module). Further investigation required to find a way to capture this correctly.
column4: Changes in SVN Externals do not generate correct Fisheye links

column3: When download artifacts, Bamboo fails to set the ContentLength header to the size of the file. The lack of the file size prevents the browser from displaying download progress properly since it cannot determine the bytes reamining.

Yesterday (13 March 2007) at 15:08:22 and 22:00:26, code was checked into our Subversion repository and the plans were not executed. We have two plans set up and the source repository configuration for both is:

Repository: Subversion 
Repository URL: svn+ssh://svn.xxx.xxx.xxx/xxx/xxx/xxx/xxx/xxx/xxx
Username: xxx
Web Repository URL: http://xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx
Build Strategy: Repository Polling
Polling Frequency: 180

See atlassian-bamboo.log for more info
column4: Bamboo throws exception when it polls Subversion repository

column3:
All plans are unable to retrieve changelogs for the files that changed.

The bamboo.log shows:
---
2007-03-13 00:05:50,943 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CVSRepository] Found 6 changes from update
2007-03-13 00:05:50,986 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CVSRepository] Running CVS log command: "log -N -r -d>2007-03-12 17:55:32 build-macros.xml AtomicLazyReference.java DefaultThreadFactory.java DefaultMessageID.java AbstractSecurityToken.java FakeProxyServer.java "
2007-03-13 00:05:50,987 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CVSRepository]                  ... in:  "/spare/bamboo/data/xml-data/build-dir/LW-COMPILE/limewire"
2007-03-13 00:05:53,154 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CVSRepository] Found 0 changes sets in the change logs
2007-03-13 00:05:53,154 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CVSRepository] something wrong with the change logs, so lets work out what's changed...
---

A little bit of detective work (by running the command and similar commands on the commandline) shows the following problems:

1) None of the files include their directories, which leads to the server knowing nothing about the files.
2) The date & time are not quoted, which leads to the server printing out a change on the given date, not at the given time.  It also causes the server to look for a change in a file whose name is the time.
3) The '>' is not escaped, which on the commandline caused the result to be piped to a file whose name was the date.  (I don't know if this effects the process the CVS command is run in.)
4) The '-r' parameter is used, which leads to only a single revision being shown.  This effectively hides any earlier commit messages on files that were updated twice between builds.

This is a huge problem.  Any help would be greatly appreciated.
column4: Never Can Retrieve Changelogs

column3: Please consider adding file include/exclude patterns for change-based build triggers.  We have scripts that run every night to automatically update foreign locale messagebundles, among other unnecessary files, and would like to prevent those changes from triggering builds in plans that use those modules.
column4: Allow include/exclude patterns for triggering build

column3:
The current Error Summary for build is whatever is piped to the the standard error log. While this works quite well with Ant, where things like compilation errors are logged to the error stream, most Maven 2 errors are logged to standard out, rendering it pretty useless.

For Maven 2 builds, we should ignore the standard error and parse std out for the errors instead. 


An example of this problem is at http://opensource.bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/STRUTS-MAIN-204

The error summary doesn't really give any useful info. It's only when you check out the "Logs" tab and scroll to the bottom, you can see that it's actually a compilation error. *This* is what we'd want in the Error Summary

 {quote}
07-Mar-2007 19:40:59  	[INFO] Compilation failure
07-Mar-2007 19:40:59 	
07-Mar-2007 19:40:59 	/home/ ​j2ee/​xml-data/​build-dir/​STRUTS-MAIN/​plugins/​tiles/​src/​main/​ java/​org/​apache/​struts2/​views/​tiles/​TilesResult.java:[104,17] cannot find symbol
07-Mar-2007 19:40:59 	symbol  : method render(java.lang.String,javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest,javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse)
07-Mar-2007 19:40:59 	location: interface org.apache.tiles.TilesContainer
07-Mar-2007 19:40:59 	
07-Mar-2007 19:40:59 	/home/ ​j2ee/​xml-data/​build-dir/​STRUTS-MAIN/​plugins/​tiles/​src/​main/​ java/​org/​apache/​struts2/​tiles/​ StrutsTilesContainerFactory.java:[85,4] org.apache.struts2.tiles.StrutsTilesContainerFactory.StrutsTilesContextFactory is not abstract and does not override abstract method createRequestContext(org.apache.tiles.TilesApplicationContext,java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object) in org.apache.tiles.context.TilesContextFactory
07-Mar-2007 19:40:59 	
07-Mar-2007 19:40:59 	/home/ ​j2ee/​xml-data/​build-dir/​STRUTS-MAIN/​plugins/​tiles/​src/​main/​ java/​org/​apache/​struts2/​tiles/​ StrutsTilesContainerFactory.java:[102,49] cannot find symbol
07-Mar-2007 19:40:59 	symbol  : method createRequestContext(org.apache.tiles.TilesApplicationContext,java.lang.Object[])
07-Mar-2007 19:40:59 	location: interface org.apache.tiles.context.TilesContextFactory
{quote}
column4: Error summarry should parse logs in Maven 2 builds

column3: When any perforce command executes, it should debug *all* of its output to the log.debug stream\r\n\r\nThis is so we can tell people to add a logging level for their Perforce commands to enable debug logging if they have problems (we should add a commented out version of this to the log.4j.properties)
column4: Perforce commands need better logging

column3: If you try to test the JIRA integration without having the remote API turned on is handled poorly - you can only find this out by looking in the server log (see attached). The GUI just prints an error statement 'Failed to connect to remote JIRA server'. This error reporting could be handled better in the GUI.
column4: Not having JIRA's Remote API enabled is handled poorly

column3:
When you enter a malformed email address to the build notifications screen, the build notifications fail silently.

An example is foo.bar.@domain.com.

Bamboo fails to send emails, but this failure doesn't appear anywhere (apart from the server log - see attached).

I suggest you parse the email address when the screen is edited rather than at the point of time when the notification event gets triggered.
column4: Entering syntactically incorrect mail recipiants is handled poorly

column3:
We have duplicate JARs in our classpath. Having two of these buggers is a recipe for unruly behaviour.

# commons-logging 1.0.4 and 1..0
# commons-beanutils-core-1.7.0.jar & commons-beanutils-1.6.jar
# opensymphony-oscore-2.2.4.jar & oscore-oscore-2.2.4.jar


We need to pretty much figure out where the dupe jars are coming from and then "exclude" it from the pom.xml
column4: Duplicate JARs in classpath

column3: This is due to the Mail jar not being compiled for JDK 1.4.
column4: Bamboo fails to start under JDK 1.4

column3:
The pom.xml in the template project refers to a com.atlassian.bamboo:atlassian-bamboo-web:1.1-SNAPSHOT dependency.

Given that the plugin would presumably be built against a stable version of Bamboo (e.g. 1.0.1), it's probably not appropriate to link to a snapshot API. A quick look around the Atlassian repository indicates that there is no published version as yet.

Pom snippet:

	<!-- This is the dependency to bamboo -->
    <dependency>
      <groupId>com.atlassian.bamboo</groupId>
	  <artifactId>atlassian-bamboo-web</artifactId>
	  <version>1.1-SNAPSHOT</version>
	</dependency>
column4: Bamboo Plugin Dev Kit pom.xml has a snapshot dependency.

column3: On days in which a new build is not made (usually holidays and weekends), Bamboo shows these days as points with no data. At a managerial and visual standpoint, seeing 0 tests, or 0 coverage can take on the wrong meaning. Perhaps some sort of ignoring days where there is no data can help.

column3:
If you setup your queues to only accept certain plans, meaning that new plans may *never* have a chance to build, this will cause the process to continuously check out and build 

The problems lies in the {{InitialBootstapBuildStrategy}} which *always* require a clean build, maybe we can just get rid of this.


From http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257243233&tstart=0#257243233
column4: If an initial build has no queues to go into, it may cause repeated clean builds
at com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.svn.SvnRepository.getChangesSinceLastBuild(SvnRepository.java:298)\r\n

column3:
About a week ago, a test Bamboo installation I have set up on a Windows 2003 server started to have an error when trying to browse to it, both from the local machine it is installed on and remotely. I have also tried using both IE and Firefox. The error started when 1.0-rc1 had been in use for a while and still exists after an upgrade to rc2. 

On thing that may be a factor is licences. If the test licences for beta copies last 30 days, it could be the case that the licence I am using has run out. However, the error doesn't give an indication this is the case and Bamboo still seems to be running build plans. The email with my licence key in it doesn't provide information as to when the licence is valid until.

When trying to browse to http://host:8085, IE gives an error saying "The page cannot be displayed". Firefox gives a more detailed error:

===============
The page isn't redirecting properly
Firefox has detected that the server is redirecting the request for this address in a way that will never complete.
*  This problem can sometimes be caused by disabling or refusing to accept
    cookies.
===============
column4: Redirection error when browsing to Bamboo pages

column3:
There was an issue that said we should remove all the tabs with the author information from the User Profile page.

This was intended to only effect the *current* user's profile page. ie when you click on "Profile" on the top right, you see your profile and no author information.

However, when you click on *other* user's names and you should still go to the page withe authors info on it. In effect, the Profile page and the User / Author info pages should be separate actions
column4: User page no longer show tabs with author information on them

column3:
It would be great to have an IDE plugin for Eclipse and/or IntelliJ IDEA to allow users to view code changes and test failures in the build system and then with one click have the change or failing test open in the IDE.

The plugin should support the option for personal builds that pass all tests to be automatically committed to the repository as described at BAM-1313
column4: Add IDE integration with Eclipse and IntelliJ IDEA plugins

column3: As the "Base URL" mainly affects links in mails bamboo sends out it should be contained in the test mail you send in the mail configuration. Therefore it's easier to see if mail configuration AND base url have been set up properly.
column4: test mail should contain clickable base url
Admin Users should be able to manually reset a user's password.
Add project/plan key to build-number.txt in build directory.

column3: We're using the Java Service Wrapper to run Bamboo standalone. Sometimes, the right wrapper isn't available for a platform (e.g. BAM-851) and we need a way for them to run Bamboo outside the wrapper.

column3: A remote API which emulates a manual build.\r\n\r\nAuthentication should be done via the normal login/auth key rather than a trusted IP address.
column4: Remote API for manual checkout and build.

column3:
Our project Apache Directory Trunk here http://opensource.bamboo.atlassian.com/browse/APACHE-DS is not triggered to build when we induce changes on the underlying directories because they are all externals.  Meaning we use svn:externals to bring together all the ApacheDS components to build the entire server.  Here's what our svn:externals property looks in the directory which is checked out by our project:

apacheds https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/directory/apacheds/trunk
shared https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/directory/shared/trunk
daemon https://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/directory/daemon/trunk

Due to this any real work done in these directories does not trigger a build.  I suspect to trigger builds properly these externals should be configured for the trigger specification of the project.  This way the updated version numbers for these external directories can also be used when determining the criteria to trigger a build.

Thanks!
column4: Commit changes do not trigger builds due to the use of SVN:externals

column3:

column3:
It seems that my solution wasn't perfect afterall, because it breaks Bamboo's change detection. I would file an issue about this, but your Jira seems to be down at the moment. So I'll describe it here and create the issue later. The problem is propably related to a CVS bug described here: http://ximbiot.com/cvs/manual/cvs-1.11.22/cvs_18.html#SEC162 I have multiple modules under CVS root grouped under one ampersand module called "orgh". The modules -file looks like this. orgh &OrgHallintaPOM &OrgHallinta &OrgHallintaAPI &OrgHallintaEntityEJB .... When I make change in OrgHallintaPOM/pom.xml, Bamboo tries to execute command "cvs log -N -r -d>2007-02-02 13:41:01 pom.xml" in orgh -directory instead of orgh/OrgHallintaPOM -directory. -----8<-----8<-----8<----- INFO: Running CVS command: 'update -d -P '
... in: 'D:/bamboo/xml-data/build-dir/ORGHAL-CI/orgh' 2007-02-02 13:50:46,474 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] ? D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh uild-number.txt 2007-02-02 13:50:46,474 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] ? Directory D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh\OrgHallinta arget 2007-02-02 13:50:46,474 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] ? Directory D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh\OrgHallintaAPI arget 2007-02-02 13:50:46,474 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] ? Directory D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh\OrgHallintaEntityEJB arget 2007-02-02 13:50:46,474 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] ? Directory D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh\OrgHallintaJava arget 2007-02-02 13:50:46,474 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] ? Directory D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh\OrgHallintaPanWeb arget 2007-02-02 13:50:46,474 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] ? Directory D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh\OrgHallintaPersistenssi arget 2007-02-02 13:50:46,474 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] ? Directory D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh\OrgHallintaSamWeb arget 2007-02-02 13:50:46,474 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] ? Directory D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh\OrgHallintaSessionEJB arget 2007-02-02 13:50:46,474 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] ? Directory D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh\OrgHallintaTehtavanHallinta arget 2007-02-02 13:50:46,646 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] ? Directory D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh\OrgHallintaTest arget 2007-02-02 13:50:47,583 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [CvsUpdateLogListener] U D: amboo\xml-data uild-dir\ORGHAL-CI\orgh\OrgHallintaPOM\pom.xml 2.2.2007 13:50:48 com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.cvsimpl.CVSRepository getChangesFromCommand INFO: Found 1 changes from update 2.2.2007 13:50:48 com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.cvsimpl.CVSRepository getChangeLogs INFO: Running CVS log command: "log -N -r -d>2007-02-02 13:41:01 pom.xml " 2.2.2007 13:50:48 com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.cvsimpl.CVSRepository getChangeLogs INFO: ... in: "D:/bamboo/xml-data/build-dir/ORGHAL-CI/orgh" 2.2.2007 13:50:48 com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.cvsimpl.CVSRepository getChangeLogs INFO: Found 0 changes sets in the change logs 2.2.2007 13:50:48 com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.cvsimpl.CVSRepository collectModuleChanges INFO: something wrong with the change logs, so lets work out what's changed... -----8<-----8<-----8<----- Is this something you can have fixed before the 1.0 release? I think many Eclipse and IBM RAD users with CVS are affected by this because this repository layout seems to be the default with these tools. The alternative workaround is not acceptable for us, because we are setting up a shared build environment for multiple projects and this aproach would generate hundreds of build plans. Having to use the modules -file is a bit hackish anyway and better solution would of course be to allow multiple modules under one plan. If branch or tag could be defined individually for the modules, this could be used for some configuration management too.
column4: Bamboo Change detection - Picking up wrong subdirectory for cvs log

column3: Lots of people do :ext (ssh) CVS using private keys. jsch supports this, but you don't provide a UI to configure it to use one. This is related to BAM-691, for which this would be a possible workaround/solution.
column4: Support for SSH private key authentication (possible using jsch)

column3:
We had a Bamboo dashboard page open in Firefox in the background. The computer got slower and slower until we noticed that Firefox was taking most of the CPU and consuming 450MB.

Closing Firefox there was a message saying that a script was unresponsive, did we want to cancel it. We did.

Haven't tried to reproduce :-)
column4: Firefox left on a Bamboo page leaks memory and hogs CPU

column3: I used the installer to install on Windows.  However on completion the only thing in the Bamboo program menu was 'Uninstall'.  To start Bamboo I had to consult the documentation, start-up a command-shell, find the installation dir on the hard-disk and run a script.  It would be nice to have an entry in the program menu to do this.
column4: No program-start menu entry created on installation with the windows installer

column4: Option to configure Unix or Win32 line breaks for CVS repository

column3: We would like to customize the look & feel of bamboo, just like jira&confluence (color scheme, logo gif). Please add this to the administration menu.
column4: configurable look and feel for bamboo

column3:
It would be really handy if we could pass in various bamboo parameters such as project key, plan key and build number to the script builder

Some variable substitution in the arguments list perhaps? e.g. ${bamboo.project.key} ${bamboo.plan.key} ${bamboo.build.number}

It may also be useful to have these set as system properties in the maven builders.

The uses for this may be many but the use case I am considering at the moment is to have web container port numbers generated by hashing these values together, automating the selection of ports for builds running on the same box.
column4: Pass in bamboo parameters such as project and plan key to builders

column3: Currently the svn+ssh connector seems to require a username and password. We'd like to auth using private key instead. I note you're using tmatesoft for svn, which supports svn+ssh with keys, so this shouldn't be too hard to achieve.
column4: svn+ssh support for private key auth

column3:
IE 7.0.5730.11 occasionally fails to display the build information page.

You could be looking at the build information page and IE will throw up a windows error dialog - see screenshot

you can then refresh the page and IE displays the page, it can then repeat
column4: IE 7 sometimes can't display build page

column3:
The statement "This build was the result of a dependency that got built." that appears on the summary tab of a dependent build sounds a little clumsy and wordy.

Perhaps something more like "This build occurred because of a dependency build." would be a little less awkward.
column4: Clumsy wording in dependency build cause
IM bot should reconnect before sending message if it was disconnected
No tab initially selected on dashboard

column3:
The new build list UI looks great, but could do with some usability improvements.

1. Click anywhere on the title to expand/collapse the display.
2. Show more information on the title bar - status, pass/fail, and when it last ran. I shouldn't have to expand to see these three key pieces of info.
3. Remember which builds were expanded when I come back to the dashboard. If #1 and #2 are fixed, this might not be necessary. Review after they're complete.

I've attached a screenshot of the current display on keg.
column4: Improve build list UI

column3:
Currently our build runs about 8800 tests.  When we click on a build and go to the test tab it takes about a minute for the first tests to display on the page and over 10 minutes before we can do anything at all (the page completely locks up).  I can't tell you how long it takes before the page loads because I've never had the patience to wait longer then about 11 minutes.  This will hinder us being able to go live with this product.

Also when we click on a plan and then click on the Tests tab it tries to load for a few seconds then says "Done" on the bottom of the screen but still displays the Plan Summary page.

If needed we can send you the xml files from our tests.
column4: Build test result tab taking to long to load.

column3: This could be because I still haven't had a successful build - but the failed builds still have a duration and more than zero tests.\r\n\r\nStrangely, the Summary page for the build plan does display the build duration and the number of test failures.  But the charts on the reports page do not show any data.
column4: Report graphs are not displaying data: build duration and # of tests
Disabled plans should have visual cue on the Summary page.

column3: When validation of repository fails, the error message is non-descript enough and do not provide sufficient detail to get it correct. http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=15389&tstart=0
column4: Better error reporting when validation of repository fails, including the command used.

column3: We need to pass in other java opts (e.g. javax keystore) to Bamboo.
column4: Cannot pass java opts to standalone version

column3: We're having a few performance problems on a project (database and Lucene indexing).  We're extracting stats from the tests. It would be great if Bamboo had hooks that we could add custom data that can be graphed by Bamboo so we could see how this data changes across builds.\r\n\r\nThat would be very cool!
column4: We able to add custom project specific Build Telemetry data

The following JARs need to be included for Crowd to work:

commons-codec-1.3.jar
commons-collections-3.1.jar
commons-httpclient-3.0.jar
commons-logging-1.0.4.jar
jaxen-1.1-beta-9.jar
jdom-1.0.jar
oscache-2.3.jar
spring-1.2.8.jar
stax-api-1.0.1.jar
wsdl4j-1.5.2.jar
wstx-asl-2.9.3.jar
xfire-all-1.2.1.jar

The most important one here is the {{commons-httpclient-3.0.jar}} must be version 3.0 or higher because of a library change after rc3 otherwise the existing version of the libs can be used EXCEPT for the httpclient.

Attached are the new sample configuration files.

column3:
As discussed in the [forums|http://forum.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257240764&#257240764] (copied below for completeness); allow for option to have parent builds block children.  This would allow children projects to use the most recent libraries from the parent, and prevent false positive builds where the parent is broken, or breaks compatibility.  A side affect is that this also makes the build sequence more efficient by not building children that would obviously fail (when parent is failing).
----
Original response in forum:

Basil,

So what you want is the ability to "block" dependent builds when a parent build is running? e.g.

Build A has child builds B, C and D is a child of C.

If I check into all the sources simultaneously (though obviously A has to build first), then you'd want A to build, and B & C not to build until A is finished? And D not until C is finished? Are you doing this so since the child builds uses the libraries in the their builds?
> Basil: Yes, that is correct.

Also, if A build fails, B and C would not build. Would that be okay?
> Basil: Yes that is what's expected.
column4: "Block" dependent builds when a parent build is running

column4: Manual build strategy gobbles up CVS errors

column3:
Some people have CVS_RSH property set to work with sshagent so that they don't need to enter passwords for SSH connections.

This is currently ignored by Bamboo and a password is required to be entered. 

We should investigate to see if we can make this work by added CVS_RSH property to the environment of the CVS Client.

I *suspect* this should be possible. See

http://www.netbeans.org/kb/articles/sourceforge.html
http://www.netbeans.org/kb/articles/cvs-ssh.html
column4: CVS Client should use the CVS_RSH environment variable if available

column3: On the configure mail page, if you enter details of your mail server (and not the JNDI settings), you still see the JNDI label on the view screen
column4: Rougue JNDI mail settings label

column3: It would be great if it was possible to add a 'special' type of comment for a build if it's broken, which would be displayed on the dashboard until the build is fixed.  That way, developers would know straight away why a build is failing on the dashboard, even if in the meantime other builds ran that also failed.  (Currently the little comment icon is only displayed for the build against which the comment was made...if the build runs again and fails again, you do not see that comment icon anymore).  In other words a 'Why was the build broken message' that doesn't go away until the build is fixed.\r\n\r\n
column4: Manual build broken message displayed on the Dashboard until a build is fixed.

column3: Queues can pick what build plans they are applicable to. However, when you delete a plan, this doesn't get removed.\r\n\r\nWe need to add this the relationship through Hibernate so that any deletes can be easily cascaded.
column4: Deleting builds doesn't seem to remove it from Queues

column3: Anywhere that references a change should (please?) have a web link to the Perforce changlist, or file, that changed (like in Jira!) Knowing *what* changed is a good start, but it would be convenient to be able to click on it and see the dffs, history, etc.
column4: Add web link to perforce changelist

column3: Have a 'picker' interface for adding projects to build queues (two windows, arrows to shuffle selections between them.)\r\n\r\nWe only have about 10 builds right now, but if I want to manage a build queue I ofter forget to hold down the Control key before I select or un-select an item in a queue's list, thusly wiping out my previous selections.
column4: Checkboxes for build queues

column3: Typing in a bunch of e-mail addresses for notifications is a chore. It would be nice to have a 'picker' for this, which uses the userlist to populate the notification list. Or better yet, allow users to subscribe to builds by clicking a link (like in Jira.)
column4: Picker for e-mail notifications

column3:

{queue}
Detected that build "CAT - CPA" needs building.
Placing build "CAT - CPA" on the build queue.
{queue}

column3: Currently Bamboo feels very sluggish over a slow network since it download all the JS files with every hit. We need to implement a version of the URL rewrite filter to see if we can fix this.
column4: Set caching headers for static files

column3:
On Build Configuration page, if you click "edit" button it allows you to change settings on all available tabs - Plan Details, Source Repository, Builder Configuration, etc. You can switch to any tab and make changes. If you switch back to can see the the changes are still preserved. However, if you click save button, only changes in the current tab will be saved. Changes in other tabs are lost.

For example, if I change Builder JDK in Builder Configuration tab to some other value then switch to Source Repository tab and click save, the change I made is reverted back to the original.

I am not sure is this the expected behavior or a bug. But in my case, it is quite confusing.
column4: Configuration changes are lost if save in an other tab

column3: JIRA tabs shows up regardless of whether you enable JIRA integration or not. This causes the link to "show related issues" to fail
column4: JIRA tabs shows up regardless

column3:
On this page:

  http://opensource.bamboo.atlassian.com/build/admin/buildConfiguration.action?buildKey=SITEMESH-TOMCAT5517

You can see that the configuration tabs are of different sizes.  I presume that you want to 'nowrap' them (or whatever the css equivalent is).
column4: Edit configuration needs formatting fixes

column3: On step 5 of setting up a project, if the 'javascript' checkbox isn't shown, then you can't create a project, as the save button isn't shown.  See screenshots.
column4: No way to 'complete' setting up a project as 'save' hidden by javascript

column3: I tried to remove a couple of dependant builds from a particular build by unchecking the relevant checkboxes.  After I submitted, the builds were still there.\r\n\r\nOn 0.10, none of the checkboxes were checked.
column4: Checkboxes dont work properly when removing dependant builds

column3:
Today Sam and I hit a weird failure in Tangosol that we haven't seen before. We wanted to search all the logs and test results of our Confluence acceptance test builds to see if it has happened anywhere before.

Give me a search box on the front page that searches all the content in Bamboo. Some ideas for stuff that should be possible:

- project, plan and build keys should jump to the summary page
- a test class name should list the plans which have results for a test with that name
- usernames or full names of users could do something.

I'm sure there's more.

Anyway, you need a search bar. At a minimum it should index all the test output.
column4: Search everything
Split webapp WAR module into a JAR and a WAR modulde

column3: When a build is triggered, it will only build if something has changed. Sometimes you want to be able to add file patterns to ignore for files that you don't build even if it's changed. (So you can check files in as a post process with the Bamboo build number in it).
column4: Ability to ignore file patterns for updates
Builds list for reports doesn't use the "pretty username"

column3: Favourites should be automatically for users if they commit to a project
column4: Auto favourite functionality

column3: Create a custom plugin which tags the build if an out of memory error has been detected.
column4: Sample plugin: Out of Memory tagging

column3: There should be a tab displaying the most recent build in Bamboo, which should be be filterable
column4: Add Recent Activity tab for the dashboard
Breadcrumbs should have build numbers
Test summary page still using the old style

column3: The build summary page should display the test cases from the author's perspective. eg. it groups the test cases by who is responsible for them.\r\n\r\nWe can reuse the UI look and feel for current test cases, and make sure that you can flip between the two views (since both can be useful). Maybe it can just be another tab.
column4: Test reponsibility for a build summary
Link tests with corresponding file in FishEye

column3: Currently goes to the dashboard, but should probably go to the Plan Summary page
column4: Redirect after a plan is created

column3: IE caches the request for ajax content.\r\n\r\nWhen submitting new comments and labels, the new content does not show up.
column4: IE caches ajax response for comments and labels
Last screen of create build broken on Safari

column3: Reloading the page every time you add a favourite means it takes about 10 minutes to add all my favourites on panda. A major hassle.
column4: AJAXify favourites

column3:
Despite the fact that dependent builds and scheduled builds aren't trigged by a code change, Bamboo should keep track of the code changes it received when it runs the update from the version control system.

For example:

1. Bamboo builds FOO-DEF-1 as a clean checkout. No code changes known.
2. Bamboo gets FOO-DEF-2 triggered as a dependent build.
3. Bamboo runs 'cvs up' in FOO-DEF build directory. Output of CVS includes files which are updated. Bamboo should capture this list and show them as code changes, exactly the same as for a code-change-triggered build.

The same is possible for scheduled build. A nightly build should show a list of all changes from the last day.
column4: Capture code changes for dependent and scheduled builds

column3: Plans should be grouped by project on the dashboard for readability and clearer design.\r\n\r\nIt makes the project concept much more useful.
column4: Display project, plan hierarchy on dashboard

column3:
In the build configuration screen, there's a label:

"What do should builds completed be labelled as?"

It should be written as:

"What should completed builds be labelled as?"

Or even better in the declarative:

"Label all successful builds"
column4: Label grammar

column3: Currently plan keys must be 3 or more characters. You should allow two characters, I think, given the whole length of the identifier is longer than JIRA.\r\n\r\nE.g.: CONF-TM-387
column4: Allow two character plan keys

column3:
Test output logs are escaped in HTML one too many times. So you end up with this:

http://panda:8080/bamboo/build/viewBuildResultsTests.action?buildKey=CONFTPC-RAND&buildNumber=31

"Expected text 'Test Spring Component' not found in response '<html>
<head>
    <title>Plugin Manager - Confluence</title>
    ..."

What it should be is this:

"Expected text 'Test Spring Component' not found in response '<html>
<head>
    <title>Plugin Manager - Confluence</title>
    ...."
column4: HTML in test output log is doubly-escaped

column4: error displaying build queue admin page

column3:
Not sure how close it relates, but it would seem we get a lot of {quote} java.io.IOException: Too many open files {quote} which consequently cause the build to fail 10 times then disable itself. Happened in version 0.7 as well, not in 0.3 and 0.5. Only happens on our linux box, not the two windows machines (different error has occurred on windows, logged separately) So the latest error in the logs would be {quote} 2006-12-27 14:16:22,908 INFO [BAM::BuildChangeDetector] [DefaultBuildChangeDetector] Detected that build "XXX" needs building. 2006-12-27 14:16:22,926 INFO [BAM::BuildPipeline::BuildExecutor] [AbstractBuilder] Starting to build 'XXX'

column3:
It would be very useful if a build stored the SCM build identifier (i.e. SVN revision, CVS date, P4 revision) that a given build was checked out with.

This could then be used by 
 * anyone wishing to recreate a given build
 * an integration server to build and deploy the software when the build succeed (our environment is complex, and the servers doing CI are not in the same location as the integration servers which live in our datacentre). While we could cobble together 

This is related to my commentary on BAM-61; although reading that is not mandatory to understand my request.
column4: API access to the SCM repository's build identifier for a given build

column3:
1. Spelling mistake - "Bamboo will create a javascipt file that will display the current status of the build. This script can then be embedded in an html page." - javascipt should be javascript
2. href="http://ci.radarnetworks.com/bamboo-status.css" css link is wrong - should be styles/bamboo-status.css
3. The template for the script should ideally replace BUILD-KEY with the appropriate build key - just for simpler cut and paste.
4. The page should note that the .js won't be created until the next build completes (it confused me, it will confuse others!)
column4: Minor issues with the build status wizard section on the editBuildConfiguration.action page

column3: Trying to add a comment from the Build Results Summary page dies with a JS error in IE
column4: Adding a comment from the Summary page doesn't work in IE

column3:
If I create a build queue and select only some build plans, save the new queue.

All good - queue now shows those plans.

Now edit the queue. Save without reselecting the plans.

Queue will now build all plans.


Just a case of it needing to highlight selected plans when editing the queue.
column4: Build queue configuration forgets which plans you had selected
Chart URLs broken

column3: At least in a Windows environments, it appears that Maven Builder's path is only recognized as valid if there is a maven.bat file in the %MAVEN_HOME%\bin directory. For Maven 2, mvn.bat and m2.bat (deprecated) are the "out-of-the-box" batch files. Perhaps the builder could check for the presence of either of these as well.
column4: Maven builder is only recognized as valid by checking for maven.bat file.

column3:
When I put in my details (on a side not, not sure what Jira server means if you already have the server url - is this just a local reference?) I get:

{quote}

a) the null is a bit concerning
b) it seems to suggest the test issue isn't there.

The log however shows the actual error:

I'd rather it just said that my username or password was invalid, I'm guessing there's a validation step missing? Meanwhile I'll try and figure out what password I gave myself :s

column3: When you hit the help link it opens up a window with the help page. This is fine, however it also replaces the original page with the help page as well, so you not only have to close the help dialog, you have to hit back. I'm guessing this shouldn't happen.

column3: The "test" functions for IM and JIRA servers are hidden. These should be on the front page of the section (ie where "edit" button is, not hidden within it).

column3: We should check if the user ends their viewcvs URL with / and make sure we don't add another / when building urls (two // in a URL break it). Simple 'usability' fix.
column4: Web Repository URL should ensure that it doesn't create double slashes for the URL

column3: When creating a project, if you click a tab 'back' from where you are - all data is lost? (ie the "<< Back" button is not the same as the previous tab link)

column3: Disabled projects are currently shown in red or green, the entire line (text w/ links) should be grey if the build is disabled - regardless of whether it passed or failed last time it ran. \r\n\r\nIf a build has never run, it should be grey too but in the "Last Completed Builds" just put "Build never executed" so that people know it's not disabled.

column4:
the following is returned:

<response>
        <buildState>Failed</buildState>
    <buildNumber>93</buildNumber>
    <failedBuildCount>43</failedBuildCount>
    <SuccessfulBuildCount>632</SuccessfulBuildCount>
    <BuildTime>12-Dec-06 01:30</BuildTime>
</response>

1. Using an ISO standard date format for BuildTime would be preferable
2. failedBuildCount / successfulBuildCount are weirdly named - failedTestCount / successfulTestCount would make it clearer
3. consistent capitalisation (I'm a bit pedantic about stuff) - since it's early enough you can still fix things like this.

column3:
When a build completes, it's supposed to copy artifacts (as I understand it). Unfortunately this doesn't work for us - and returns an error as follows.


(Failed to copy /home/bamboo-server/home/xml-data/build-dir/APP-MAIN/output/db/classes/com/networks/db/DatabaseRuntimeException.class to /home/bamboo-server/home/xml-data/builds/APP-MAIN/download-data/artifacts/build-55/output/db/classes/com/networks/db/DatabaseRuntimeException.class due to /home/bamboo-server/home/xml-data/build-dir/APP-MAIN/output/db/classes/com/networks/db/DatabaseRuntimeException.class (No such file or directory))


Now admittedly I don't need the .class file to be copied, but it's just easier to configure that way (so I get everything), and I can't see why it wouldn't be copied.

I've checked that the .class file in question exists - and it does (I can't guarantee it exists when the copy occurs, but there's nothing magic in the build - so I'd wager it does exist).

The configuration I use in the build configuration is:

Label  	Source Directory  	Copy Pattern
output 	output 	**/*

Am I dumb, or is something amiss?
column4: Unable to copy build artifacts
