column3:
On the viewTestCase screen (getting there via the 'View test case across builds' link) shows two graphs: 'Succesful VS Failed builds' and 'Test Running Duration'. In the latter, the vertical label is wrong. Should be 'Run Time' instead of 'Build Time'.

 S.
column4: Wrong title on 'Test Running Duration' graph

column3: Some open source projects like Jetty, Wicket or OpenJPA have a large number of unit tests. Think about hundreds or even thousands. Selecting the 'tests' report is in those cases extremely slow since it takes a lot of time to build up a huge page. It would be nice if in those cases the unit tests were paginated, summarized, or dynamically loaded through AJAX. This is in the viewBuildResultsTests.action screen.
column4: Better handling of large number of unit tests

column3: I know it is possible to link to an external system that allows you to browse the subversion repository but it would be really nice if Bamboo would have this build in. I can imagine this as a [Show Diff] link in the viewBuildCommits.action screen which would then load the diff and put it in the page trhough AJAX. (Because you probably don't want to show a page with 500 big diffs)\r\n
column4: Integrated Source/Diff browser

column3: You should be to be able to tag a particular build (maybe as a release, release_0_6, broken) and then view all the builds with a particular tag.\r\n\r\nIt also allows arbitrary grouping and viewing of builds.
column4: Tagging Build Results

column3:
A new build reports feature which allows viewing of trends of key build metrics:

- number of builds
- number of failures
- ratio of successful builds
- number of tests
- duration of build.

The reports shall allow comparison of different builds on these metrics.

Data points can be grouped by time periods:
- Day
- Week
- Month.
column4: Build Reports

column3: When you reload Bamboo pages in the states, it very slow to load.\r\n\r\nI'm pretty sure this is a dojo issue since if you trun off Javascript, all is happy in the world. Need to investigate whether it's a widget parsing or just the widget loading itself.
column4: Reloading pages from remote machines is very slow.

column3: Seems to have been changed in the 0.7 release on keg. Please change it back!\r\n\r\nPeople tend to remember projects by name and therefore scan the list by name, not by key. At first glance the list looks like a complete jumble because the names aren't in order.
column4: Dashboard ordered by project key rather than name

column3:
At the moment tests detect that they were "broken" from the first time they appear in the "broken tests" list. The result of this is that if you have

| BAM-MAIN-1 | Buld Succesful |
| BAM-MAIN-2 | test.foo failed |
| BAM-MAIN-3 | Compilation failed (no tests ran) |
| BAM-MAIN-4 | test.foo failed |

test.foo actually reports as having been failing since BAM-MAIN-4. It should be intelligent enough to see that it hasn't been in the "successful" test list since BAM-MAIN-1.
column4: Tests detect when they start failing more intelligently

column3: Clearing the checkbox doesn't really work. We need to make sure that if nothing is passed, the action sets the Build Expiry property to false
column4: Cannot disable Build Expiry

column3: Include other useful batches (install-as-service, etc.)
column4: Include other useful batches (install-as-service, etc.) in installation

column3: When kicking off a manual build for the RSVP-plugin (or for any build for that matter), it does not pick up the changes in the source repository. \r\n\r\nGiven that a person kicks off a manual build when he can't be bothered to wait for the changes to be detected, it's not so much of an issue. However, the history no longer reflects all the changes made on that build.
column4: Manual build does not pick up changes

column3: This must be in upper case. if the value supplied is in lower case, could you not just switch it all to upper case automatically?
column4: build key case issue

column3: Thanks to buugs like http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/MSUREFIRE-114, sometimes the XML created by the builds can't be trusted.\r\n\r\nWe should ensure that test case result objects are stored in a set so that they can't have duplicates. This should be done at build time, so any builds that have already been completed will not be affected. Maybe we could look at an upgrade task afterwards.
column4: Bamboo should ensure test uniqueness within a build

column3:
In general, people want to look at stuff before they edit it.

If you don't think this is a good idea, feel free to close as "Won't Fix".

column3:
Currently reads:

"Confluence RPC has no dependent builds. (i.e. no other builds will be triggered after Confluence RPC successfullly builds."

Typos are missing closing parenthesis, starting a sentence without a capital ("i.e."), three els in successfully. Would perhaps be better written as:

"Confluence RPC currently has no dependent builds. That is, no other builds will be triggered after Confluence RPC successfully builds.

Click _Edit_ above to add a dependent build."
column4: Typos in "no dependent builds" message

column3:
[Raised on behalf of Randy]

Hi Edwin,

I haven't tried the 0.6 release yet, but I'm glad to see the start of a JIRA integration.  I just wanted to mention that it would be nice if this integration worked like the JIRA Perforce plug-in for users of Perforce.  That is, instead of referencing a JIRA issue number in a check-in comment, it would use Perforce jobs that are linked to JIRA issues. 

Cheers,
Randy DeFauw
column4: Commits in Perforce repository link to JIRA issues via Perforce Jobs

Saves me having to do a "chmod +x start-bamboo.sh" every time I install an update

column3: eg. "This build added 2 tests" and then display the new tests
column4: Detect tests are added and removed on top of fixes, existing failures, new failures

column3:
A post on Nabble Maven Users (http://www.nabble.com/core-api-container-outdated-on-snapshot-repository-tf2550173.html#a7110351) has given a brilliant idea for Bamboo.

For those who run on maven projects, It would be a great feature for successful nightly builds to automatically deploy to the remote repository. The build process would be something like this:

External:
(1) SVN/CVS commit new changes

Bamboo:
(2) Builds triggered, builds
(3) IF (successful build) && (maven II project) THEN run 'mvn deploy'

Some prerequisites for doing this are:
1. pom.xml must have distribution managment setup
2. bamboo server must have settings.xml setup with authentication settings.

I'm sure the guys at cargo codehaus would love you for this ;)
column4: Automate deploying for all Maven II Projects once build is successful

column3:
I selected mutliple builds to delete. When i pressed the delete button, I returned back to the main administration screen. When i clicked 'Delete Build' on the nav bar, those builds were gone. It would have been good if:

(1) I returned back to the same 'Delete Build' screen
(2) Get a confirmation message
column4: Confirmation message not given when deleting multiple builds

column3:
Currently build numbers over 1000 in IM messages use commas in the build numbers. This looks a bit silly:

> Confluence build 1,002 has FAILED (4 tests failed, no failures were new) : Change made by jschumacher

It would look better with a NumberFormat of "#", which would look like this:

> Confluence build 1002 has FAILED (4 tests failed, no failures were new). Change made by jschumacher.

(With punctuation fixed as well. ;))
column4: Use NumberFormat "#" for build numbers in instant messages

column3: We need to make sure that when the build is reenabled, the builds are ran
column4: Having all queues disabled means that commits are lost during that period

column3:
We currently have a team of 7, 3 testers and 4 developers. We are polling every 3 hours for builds to the test server. What would be nice is to be able to specify specific polling times, for example 6am ,9am, 12pm, 3pm, 6pm and 9pm. 

This means that when the testers see an issue resolved in JIRA they would be able to predict when they will be seeing that fix on the test server.

I realise that with notifications they can also do this, but there is a subtle difference in they can structure their day around a predictable schedule rather than having to work out - ok last build was at 10.17am, so the next one is going to be at around 1.17pm.
column4: Poll at specific times

column3: When I stop a build that is in the queue, the build results return as a red colour. For me, red kinda represents tests have failed. Should there be another colour for build intervention (such as compiling issues, downloading issues and so forth)?\r\n\r\n
column4: Build shows up as red when 'Delete build from queue' is clicked. Needs more netural colouring

column3:
When I create a build using Perforce for source control, it works fine immediately afterward. I can even build multiple times. But once I restart Bamboo, I get startup errors referring to Perforce, as well as messages in the error log:

Strack Trace

java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.perforce.PerforceRepository.getSourceCodeDirectory(PerforceRepository.java:108)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.DefaultBuildChangeDetector.checkIfBuildNeedsBuilding(DefaultBuildChangeDetector.java:140)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.DefaultBuildChangeDetector.doTask(DefaultBuildChangeDetector.java:100)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.DefaultBuildChangeDetector.run(DefaultBuildChangeDetector.java:68)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Unknown Source)


If I then create a new build it will build, but then once Bamboo is restarted, both projects will fail from the get-go.

I've attached a clean logfile that includes starting the server for the first time, creating a build, building it twice, stopping the build, then trying to build the same build again with no changes to any configuration.

Thanks!
column4: Perforce provider stops working after Bamboo restart

column3: The current site title is 'The Bamboo Build System - Bamboo Continuous Integration Server'. Personally this is saying the same thing twice in two ways. I'd like to be able to manually set the second half to reflect what our use of that server is.
column4: customise site title

column3: The default value for the base url is localhost. Being a webserver, this is obviously wrong. It would be better if it could use the webserver address rather than localhost.
column4: default base url is invalid

column3:
Not sure how your average time thing works. Since I used the old beetlejuice files, I think it might be incorrect.

I've removed all 'failed' builds that marked themselves as successful.  Looking through every build in the results page, the shortest build I can find is 52 minutes, the longest being 1304. Yet the average time is 45 minutes.....

I'll restart the app tonight, then re-index - never got round to it before. Then check again and see if this changes, but I can't see why it would, Also, the rss allbuilds.xml and failedbuilds.xml don't include the beetlejuice builds, but may still contain the deleted builds that were marked as successful even though they weren't.

any obvious ideas why this would be the case? I can manually calculate it to see, but if the minimum successful build is 52 I don't see how it could drop an average of 45...
column4: build timer incorrect

column3: A team I know have a south park character for each team member.  This is displayed on the page when they break the build .\r\n\r\nIt's sounds frivolous, but had a major impact on how the team responded to broken builds (previously they ignored them).  They have open sourced it http://sourceforge.net/projects/build-o-matic.  I would really like something similar in Bamboo
column4: Add photo (or fun team image) to the user, display this when they break the build

column3:
Create build link is invalid on dash:

top right link goes to [address]/build/admin/buildWizardSourceCode!default.action?mode=Add
link on dash goes to [address]/admin/build/admin/buildWizardSourceCode!default.action?mode=Add

extra 'admin' in there
column4: create build link wrong on dash
Build Queues should be able to choose which projects it would accept

column3: It seems that the upgrade tasks don't really run in order at the moment. Might not be a problem at the moment, but it sure will be in the future
column4: Upgrade tasks don't run in order

column3: We have a build setup under cvs. We have now moved to svn, and want to switch. Although it gives the option to change the repository to svn, it doesn't seem to want to save it.... and so reverts back to cvs
column4: Cannot change version repositories

column3: Create a JIRA plugin that displays related Bamboo builds as an issue panel
column4: Bamboo build panel for JIRA issues

column3: Each build has commit messages which may contain JIRA keys. Bamboo should parse the builds for issue keys and display the issues' information for each build
column4: Displaying related JIRA issues in Bamboo
Allow configuration at a project level to be over-ridden at a build level

column3: I'd like to be able to use a different filter for the number of builds displayed on the project summary page and results page.\r\n\r\nI'd like to see all builds on the summary page because the are grouped and do not take long to display, and it's a nice coverage of build history. However I don't want to see them all individually on the results page as after 800 it takes forever to load the page - I'd personally keep this down to 30 or 60 days max.
column4: Pagination for summary/results page

column3:
Today I wanted to see how fast the number of tests in Confluence is increasing.

I think this would be a useful graph to put on the 'Tests' page of the build -- the number of total tests vs time/builds (perhaps green-red stacked bars).

http://keg.sydney.atlassian.com:8080/bamboo/build/viewTestsSummary.action?buildKey=CONFMVN2
column4: Add tests graph to Tests page of build
Pagination for the build results history table

column3: same username
column4: Signup page causes 500 error when trying to create a duplicate user

column3:
I am evaluating CI tools which may serve us as alternatives to CruiseControl.

We are a quite advanced user of CI tools. I am looking at Bamboo, Team City and the other existing ones. With Team City and Bamboo, they are obviously new products and their feature sets are uncertain.

We would be more inclined to take the plunge with Bamboo if we knew where it was heading. One of the best feature matrixes I have seen is the on the DamageControl guys have done. See http://docs.codehaus.org/display/DAMAGECONTROL/Continuous+Integration+Server+Feature+Matrix.

I would love to see where you are heading expressed in something similar. Or failing that, any sort of roadmap at all.

I am downloading each of the alphas and playing with them, but at some point we need to determine whether to try and use it for real.
column4: Would like to see a feature list along the lines of http://docs.codehaus.org/display/DAMAGECONTROL/Continuous+Integration+Server+Feature+Matrix

Personally I'm not that bothered about previous build logs, just wanted the generic checkin data to be there, so simply catching this error and saying 'no log data found' or something would be satisfactory

column4: Tries to Diff initial version of file with previous version

column3:
If you have a build that is disabled, and you try to "checkout & build build", then nothing happens.  While it is reasonable that "checkout & build build" doesn't work when the build is disabled I think the current behaviour is very unfriendly.

Really, I'd like to be able to trigger a build manually even if automatic building is disabled,
However, there should otherwise be a message saying that the build will not happen because the build is disabled.

Maybe if having the build disabled is meant to stop the user manually triggering a build, then the "c & b b" button should be disabled too.  (I actually like giving error messages better than disabling controls, because it can be difficult for a user to ascertain why a control is disabled, but on the other hand it is a bit mean to provide a button that won't work, because the user doesn't realise it won't work until they press it. )
column4: Disabled build should also hide the build option

column3: It should give an example so there's no confusion if it's bamboo.home or BAMBOO_HOME.\r\n\r\n

column3: One of the primary reasons for selecting Bamboo over Zutubi's Pulse or Jetbrains TeamCity would be the potential for tight integration between the build server both Jira and Confluence.  As a start it would be nice to see what Jira issues were included in each build.\r\n\r\nI could continue on the theme and say it would be nice to publish artifacts in Confluence either autmoted with each build or as a designated push especially around release time.
column4: Display related jiras in a build

column3:
From http://forums.atlassian.com/message.jspa?messageID=257234648#257234648


Hi,
It looks as if there's an installation name issue...

I first installed the Windows standalone, specifing my own root of D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo but keeping the default suffix of _0.4. I also specified an alternative BambooHome outside the app directory.

When I came to run it, I found that nothing happened, so I downloaded the .zip version, unzipped that to \Bamboo, set the BambooHome (in fact, copied it from the previous install) and run that, whereupon it ran up correctly.

I compared the two trees and was surprised to see that apart from the .install4j folder (surely not needed in the .zip archive?) they were identical, and was even more surprised to see the following behaviour!

{noformat}
D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo_0.4>start-bamboo.bat
Press any key to continue . . .
D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo_0.4>cd ..

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>mv Bamboo_0.4 Bamboo04

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>cd Bamboo04

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo04>start-bamboo.bat
2006-09-28 09:44:41,946 INFO [main] [HttpServer] Version Jetty/5.1.4
2006-09-28 09:44:41,977 INFO [main] [Credential] Checking Resource aliases
2006-09-28 09:44:42,587 INFO [main] [Container] Started org.mortbay.jetty.servlet.WebApplicationHandler@1abab88
Terminate batch job (Y/N)? y

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo04>cd ..

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>mv Bamboo04 Bamboo_0.4

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>cd Bamboo_0.4

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo_0.4>start-bamboo.bat
Press any key to continue . . .
D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo_0.4>cd ..

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>mv Bamboo_0.4 Bamboo04

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration>cd Bamboo04

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo04>start-bamboo.bat
2006-09-28 09:46:04,916 INFO [main] [HttpServer] Version Jetty/5.1.4
2006-09-28 09:46:04,956 INFO [main] [Credential] Checking Resource aliases
Terminate batch job (Y/N)? y

D:\Java\Continuous_Integration\Bamboo04>
{noformat}

Just to continue, Bamboo_04 & Bamboo0.4 are OK, but not Bamboo_0.4 !

/Gwyn
column4: start-bamboo.bat  fails to run when the folder name has a . and a _ in it
Error page should link back to the home page

column3:
If you create a new build or edit it from the icon on the right you have the options of 

The Trunk
A Branch

However if you veiw the build config then edit the cvs section on it's own you get

HEAD
Branch/Tag


I vote for consistency, and personally prefer head over trunk. Branch/Tag is fine

ps You need to add a 'cosmetic' issue type
column4: cvs branch/head consistency

column3: More and more people are actually using Bamboo and need to upgrade. We need to create a step by step guide to show them how this can be done

column3: A 'Save' button on every Page so save minor edits would be Great!
column4: Save functionality on every Page of Wizard

column3:
Currently Bamboo has a Dashboard which displays build summary irrespective of weather the user has logged in or not.

This should be configurable via the Admin Page if the dashboard should be displayed or not for guest users.

Also there should be a Panel in RED informing the user that they have not logged in above the Dashboard.
column4: Configurable Permissions for Dashboard

column3:
Ability to associate cetain admin users with certains projects.
This will bring into play a super-admin-user who will be able to configure all the users.

Similarly Builds can be configured to be viewed by a restricted set of users. 

In a software services company. You many not want clients to see builds of other projects
column4: Permissions for User and Groups
Changing context path seems to cause installation to fail

column3:
Not sure how to mark this one up. If i kill a build partway (say my 2hour build is cut at about 10 mins) it says it's successful. This wouldn't be a problem if it then meant the build queue timer was then updated to include this, thus becoming miles out of what it should be.

I'd like it be marked with something like suspended, or not all tests run - kinda like a 3-state boolean :).

Actually this is quite open. Personally I'd say a build stopped short is a failure as you can't prove your code works unless you run the entire suite. Thus it should be marked as a failure. However, I may be narrow-minded in this thinking....
column4: Cancelling a build part way is marked as a successful build

column3: If I'm not mistaken this is showing up in US format - 10/5/06 is mm/dd/yy? Should really be consistent - build details show up as dd/mm/yyyy so this would be more useful - it's also then in UK format :). \r\n\r\nMainly for conformity across the entire application the date format should be the same or configurable.
column4: Support period date in incorrect format

column3: Not sure how this would work, but it would definitely be cool. You'd need to read the POM and the POMs of other projects and relate them.\r\n\r\nAlso, dependencies should be at the project level, rather than the build level, once you introduce this split.
column4: Determine dependencies from Maven

column3: cvs password is optional. it says so. if you leave it blank on creating the project it doesn't mind. However, if you go back to it later and edit the repository data (updateBuildRepository.action) and then try to save, it says 'repository.cvs.password.required'... but it's optional....\r\n\r\nThink there's a check there that doesn't need to be :)
column4: Optional field appears to be mandatory on update (cvs password)

column3: As Bamboo is Beetlejuice reskinned (plus some), it seems odd (maybe I missed it) that there is no current upgrade option to take current beetlejuice setup's and convert them over to the new bamboo setup. I'd imaging this hinderance to the beetlejuice community (if I haven't missed the option - i'll keep looking but there was nothing in the new install) is unnecessary. Will raise a bug relating the the actual error shortly.
column4: Upgrade option from beetlejuice

column3: I would prefer that if I asked a log page to refresh every 10 seconds, when I went back to it or any other log page, they also had their refresh times set to 10seconds\r\n\r\nWhether this is maintained per user (being a web app i'm aware that's an issue) or just per session (probably easier) is not a problem. Personally if i leave the app and go back to it I don't mind as much if the refresh is reset. Or in a pointless options style, you could add it to the user preferences screen :s (it's an option, not a suggestion)
column4: Keep refresh option for logs

column3:
Bamboo is a multi-threaded app and I don't doubt we'll run into some issues with this sooner or later.

We should implement the Thread debugging page as per http://www.javaspecialists.co.za/archive/newsletter.do?issue=132&locale=en_US

Since this will require Java 5, we also need to create a special module which will house code that requires Java 5. Any code that requires Java 5 needs to be behave defensively, so that I will still run under 1.4 (gives nice error messages)
column4: Add ThreadDump page for debugging client problems

column3: Errors appearing in the error log are associated with a build project, but they are not associated with a particular build or timestamp. It would be good to know whether they were the cause or result of some particular build failure...
column4: Error Log needs more context eg. build no, timestamp.
Create Commit Page
Create Author Pages

column3: The mail being sent out has a count of "authors". This is actually the number of commits.\r\n\r\nThis should be fixed to be the number of unique authors
column4: Mail template reporting wrong authors count

column3:
I think making the boxes consistent heights would make the UI look 100% better on the configuration screen. An inconsistent and jagged layout is the underlying problem; there may be ways to achieve it other than with the heights.

You could use this balanced column javascript:

http://www.paulbellows.com/getsmart/balance_columns/

See attached images for an example. (CSS hackery only let me use one height for all four, instead of two separate values. JS should allow this.)
column4: Make floatingPanel heights consistent across rows on Configuration screen

column3: Should link to first failing build (if not current build) and show how many builds / time it's been failing for
column4: Add a failing since link on Build Summary page
Delete a Project screen always checks the first project when clicking.

column3: Makes it easier to diagnose problems
column4: Fix up footer to include the date that the build was made as well as the build number

column3: The IM Server and the Mail Server only has an Edit screen at the moment. This is a little confusing, since after the edit, there's no where for the user to be redirected to.\r\n\r\nIt's also more user friendly to always have the View -> Edit screens available for any component
column4: View Screens for Mail Server and IM Server

column3: As part of BAM-113, we had to remove code supporting the Java Service Wrapper (http://wrapper.tanukisoftware.org/doc/english/introduction.html) which provides some pretty useful reliablility benefits.\r\n\r\nWe should try to get this reintegrated with the installer version of Bamboo for the next release.
column4: Reimplement Java Service Wrapper to be bundled as part of the standard installer

column3:
In controlfooter-core.ftl
it has
doesLabelKeyHaveMatchingDescription(parameters.labelKey)
which raises log4j warnings when there is no labelkey with matching labelkey description
column4: Can't find i18n key blah.description

column3:
The installation directory of Bamboo should be improved and the contents of the distributions revisited:

- Use a cleaner directory structure and create a webp-app directory.
- Revisit and select appropriate distributions and their relevant launchers.
- Include repository trigger scripts in distribution.
- Rename "bamboo-server" to "startup".
- Include other useful batches (install-as-service, etc.)
column4: Distributions have confusing directory structure.

column3:
While debugging our cluster build, it would be great to have an option to just build the project manually.

At the moment, the build can only be a CVS trigger or polling for changes. This means the always-broken build gets kicked off frequently, taking space in the queue and CPU when other builds could be running.
column4: Add 'change detection' option for manual build only

column3: I get IM messages at home, but then can't check the build results without a tunnel to the office.\r\n\r\nNow we have security the instance can be public, yes?
column4: Set up bamboo.atlassian.com

column3:
Seconds might still be useful when max build time for the graph is less than a minute, but for builds that take upwards of 1 minute I think a scale of minutes looks much better.

Large numbers take up more space and seconds->minutes conversion is non-metric therefore difficult to do mentally.
column4: Build time graph should use minutes in scale

column3: Currently, the quartz Scheduler is manually started and maintained in the BambooContainer itself. We should investigate how Quartz can be used inside Spirng (e.g. http://www.springframework.org/docs/reference/scheduling.html) and migrate to that way instead
column4: Update Quartz usage to utilise Spring

column3: The Zen forest page has a bug when constructing the links to the project. It adds an extra slash to the link.\r\n\r\nSee link for "Confluence Mvn2 Functional Tests" under Cold server
column4: double slash ( "\\") in link

column3:
When a file is commited to the CVS repository then it triggers the projects that are using that CVS to build.
This causes a problem when there are several projects for the one CVS. This is because some of these projects are known to be unstable and likely fail.
Therefore if there is a way to temporary diable these project builds it would reduce the number of projects in the queue.
So more time can be spent on building useful projects.
column4: Option to disable projects

column3: The link for queued projects currently points to an invalid location. This should be  {http://panda.sydney.atlassian.com:8080/functestbamboo/project/viewProjectSummary.action?projectKey=BAMFUNC} but is  {http://panda.sydney.atlassian.com:8080/functestbamboo/viewProjectSummary.action?projectKey=BAMFUNC}\r\n\r\n

column3:
I got the following message via Jabber:

[13:50] Bamboo: Confluence (Tomcat, Postgres, Cluster) build 68 has FAILED (519 tests failed, 1 failures were new) : Change made by cmiller
http://panda.sydney.atlassian.com:8080/functestbamboo/viewBuildResults.action?buildNumber=68&projectKey=CONFTPC

Clicking on the link shows that 19 failures were new. Looks like the Jabber message is counting something different to the Bamboo web site.
column4: New build failures count in Jabber message is different to web site

column3: If an exception is thrown during building, then it is caught and the Thread returns.\r\n\r\nThis results in the Build just hanging there and having to be killed manually
column4: Buid hangs if exception is thrown during build

column3: Deleting build queues work.... until you restart the server, then the build queues that you deleted mysteriously reappear.
column4: Deleting build queues don't work

column3: I was trying to set up project dependencies for the JIRA dependant projects. For the JIRA Toolkit I created dependencies to JIRA, atlassian-renderer etc. The build did not trigger when JIRA was built, and wouldn't build manually either, even after a restart. Only solution was to remove dependencies, then manually rebuild.\r\n\r\nThe dependencies feature would be particularly useful for us as we have a significant number of dependant projects that we want to setup on both the branch and head builds of JIRA, as well as common projects (like renderer) that both JIRA and Confluence depend on.
column4: Project dependencies don't work

column3:
Mysterious bug where a project appears in two different build queues (i.e. building more than once).

Not sure how to reproduce this problem.
column4: Project added to build queue more than once

column3: Currently there are no cache-control headers on the static resources (images, css etc.), so they are being downloaded every page refresh (every 10 secs). The forest page downloads 250k every time. Causes annoying visual flicker as well as increased network traffic.
column4: Static files are not cached, increases size of downloads

column3: Currently if there are some big builds in progress that consume 100% CPU, the webapp becomes entirely unresponsive. We need a xplatform way to lower the priority of the build processes so they do not interfere with the UI.
column4: Lower priority of spawned build processes

column3: Pinch the 500 and 404 pages from Confluence / JIRA to offer a more descriptive error page
column4: Add decent 404 and 500 pages

column3:
If a project attempts to build without a builder is seems that a series of things go wrong (see http://keg:8080/bamboo/viewBuildResults.action?buildNumber=497&projectKey=JIRA)

* Two build summaries gets added to the project
* Sometime the project build results are not added to the project, causing the build results page to fail catastrophically

We should perhaps validate the project before each build
column4: Bad things happen when Builders disappear

column3: When a new project is created when build queues are disabled, the project sits there constantly polling the (CVS) server. When you view the project details (by clicking edit project), the setting is set to polling even though you may of set it to build only when triggered. If you then enable the queues and the build goes through, the setting is corrected.\r\n\r\nWhen a build is kicked off from an existing project when the build is triggered, the build is 'queued' even though there are no build queues (i.e. when the build queues are enabled, the build then starts). Additionally, the 'queued' project also sits there constantly polling the server every second.
column4: Constant polling with queues disabled

column3:
The list of failed tests amd successful tests are incorrectly reported.

It seems as if only one list is kept for all successful tests in every file (i.e. one file regardless of the number of test files) and one list for all failures.

Bamboo is supposed to report the successful and failed tests in each file, however, for each file, it seems to start reading from the beginning of the list again such that it reports successes and failures for tests not in the corresponding test file.

The aggregation of numbers are out of whack too.

The build logs however, are correct.
column4: Incorrect reporting of Test Results

column3:
As part of our release process, we update and tag a particular version of Confluence in CVS. Bamboo may or may not build this exact version, depending on what other commits occur around the same time. After tagging, we check out the tag locally and build and run the tests to make sure our tagged version is okay to release or deploy. As a build server, Bamboo should be able to do this.

To run a "release build" or "tagged build", the user would select a project, select a VCS branch and tag, and Bamboo would run the normal build process and capture artifacts, etc.

Bamboo should keep a list of "release builds" or "tagged builds" separate to the normal list of builds, since the normal list of builds has a useful chronological order which release builds would disrupt.

As a secondary enhancement, the release builds should be configurable separately to the normal builds. That is, they could configured to run different maven targets (including deployment, perhaps), and capture different artifacts (JAR and WAR files, for example).
column4: Build nominated versions of projects

column3:
when viewing an error result in the log viewer, the spaces are not preserved, so you cannot visually determine the location of the error: 

/opt/bamboo/xml-data/build-dir/INV/invoice-tools/src/java/com/atlassian/invoice/parser/CurrencyParser.java:22: warning: unmappable character for encoding UTF8
protected static final String VALID_CURRENCY_SYMBOLS = "[\(\$��]";
^

(side note: the symbols are not preserved, don't know whether they are in the actual log file or not, but it would be great if it preserved the charset)
column4: Log Viewer and Build Error Results should preserve whitespace formatting

column3:
One idea: once users and groups are in Bamboo, make project notification just specify which groups and/or users to notify. Each user can then decide how she wishes to be notified. 

For example, project Confluence could notify: confluence-developers, jonathon@atlassian.com Each user would have a preference about whether they should be notified via Jabber, email or both.

There are many other possible solutions. I think we need a balance between administrator-configured notification (a la JIRA) and user-configured notification (a la Confluence). There are benefits to both.
column4: Improve configuration of notifications

There seems to be occasions when the project is building but does not appear on the visible queue and vise versa. Generally, the triggered builds work fine, but it's just the UI build queue that seems out of whack. Keeping two sperate lists is probably not a great idea

Need to investigate this further.

One possible solution would be to migrate existing queues to ActiveMQ queses since it (apparently) allows for queues to be _browsed_
